section.heading: Marking of ballot papers for or by incapacitated person

subsection.content: The Presiding Officer may mark a ballot paper for a voter or authorized representative who is or claims that he or she is unable to read or is incapacitated from voting due to blindness or other physical cause. The Presiding Officer may do so only on the application of such a voter or authorized representative.

The Presiding Officer must mark the ballot paper for a person referred to in subsection (1) in the presence of a polling officer and in the appropriate manner specified in section 56, according to the choice of the voter or authorized representative. The Presiding Officer must put the ballot paper into the ballot box in the presence of a polling officer and in the appropriate manner described in section 54, after marking it.

A voter or authorized representative who is blind or claims that he or she is blind may make use of a template to mark the ballot paper if a template is provided for that purpose at the polling station.

section.name: s58
section.heading: When person is to be issued with ballot paper marked “重複” and “TENDERED”

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2) and section 55, if a person (the first-mentioned person) representing himself or herself to be a particular voter or authorized representative registered in the subsector final register applies for a ballot paper after a person has been issued with a ballot paper earlier on the basis that he or she is that first-mentioned person, the Presiding Officer must issue to the first-mentioned person a ballot paper endorsed on the front of it with the words “重複” and “TENDERED”.

subsection.leadIn: The Presiding Officer may issue a ballot paper under subsection (1) only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Presiding Officer is not certain that the first-mentioned person is the person who has been issued with a ballot paper earlier; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the first-mentioned person answers the appropriate questions set out in section 51 to the satisfaction of the Presiding Officer.

section.name: s59
section.heading: What ballot papers are to be marked “未用” and “UNUSED” by Presiding Officer

subsection.content: Unless it is not reasonably practicable to do so, the Presiding Officer must endorse the words “未用” and “UNUSED” on any ballot paper that has been issued but has not been put into the ballot box, including any ballot paper kept in that Officer’s custody under section 55(4) or (6) at the close of the poll.

References in this Regulation to an “unused ballot paper” are to be construed as references to a ballot paper which has been issued and has not been put into the ballot box, whether or not it has been endorsed under subsection (1).

section.name: s60
section.heading: What ballot papers are to be marked “損壞” and “SPOILT” by Presiding Officer

subsection.content: If a voter or authorized representative inadvertently deals with the ballot paper issued to him or her in such a manner that it cannot be properly used as a ballot paper or makes an error in marking a ballot paper, he or she may apply to the Presiding Officer for another ballot paper.

The Presiding Officer may issue another ballot paper to a person referred to in subsection (1) if that person gives back the ballot paper already issued to him or her to that Officer and establishes to the satisfaction of that Officer inadvertence or the fact that he or she has made an error.
The Presiding Officer must immediately cancel the ballot paper given back to that Officer under subsection (2) by endorsing on the front of it the words “損壞” and “SPOILT”.

section.name: s61
section.heading: Steps to be taken at polling station after close of poll

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after the close of the poll at a polling station, the Presiding Officer must, in the presence of the persons, if any, who are present within the polling station, take the following steps—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: seal each ballot box with a seal provided for that purpose or with any other device specified by the Chief Electoral Officer, so that a ballot paper or any other material cannot be introduced into or withdrawn from the ballot box after it is sealed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: make up into separate sealed packets—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the un-issued ballot papers;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the unused ballot papers;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the spoilt ballot papers; and
if the copy of the subsector final register has been marked under section 53(5)(a)—the marked copy. (14 of 2021 s. 211)

subsection.content: The Presiding Officer must then comply with section 69 in relation to the ballot box, the sealed packets and the ballot paper account.

For the avoidance of doubt, it is declared that the ballot papers in a sealed packet prepared under this section are not to be processed for the purpose of the counting of votes. Accordingly, references in this Regulation to “ballot papers” in relation to the counting of votes are to be construed as not including those ballot papers. (E.R. 1 of 2020)

section.name: s62
section.heading: Presiding Officer to prepare ballot paper account
section.leadIn: For the ballot papers issued by a polling station, the Presiding Officer must prepare a statement in the specified form that shows—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the total number of ballot papers issued by the polling station;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the number of unused ballot papers;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the number of spoilt ballot papers; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the number of tendered ballot papers.

section.name: s63
section.heading: Returning Officer to give notice of time and place of counting of votes to candidates

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (6), the Returning Officer is to determine the time at which the counting of the votes in respect of a subsector election is to begin.
The time determined under subsection (1) must be a time after the poll has closed at all the polling stations at which polling for that subsector was conducted.

The Returning Officer must give notice in writing to each candidate for a subsector of the time determined for the counting of the votes for that subsector to begin and the place at which the counting is to take place.
Notice under subsection (3) must be given at least 10 days before polling day. (L.N. 114 of 2006; 15 of 2016 s. 63)
If the poll for a subsector is adjourned under Schedule 1, the counting of the votes for that subsector is to stand postponed.

If the counting of votes stands postponed under subsection (5), the Chief Electoral Officer is to determine a time for the counting to begin and the place at which it is to take place. The time must be after the adjourned poll for the subsector is resumed and after the close of that poll. The Returning Officer is to give notice to each candidate for the relevant subsector of the time and place.
A notice required to be given to a candidate under this section may be given to the election agent or counting agent of the candidate instead of to the candidate.

section.name: s64
section.heading: Candidates may appoint counting agents

subsection.content: A candidate may appoint persons to attend at a counting station to observe the counting of the votes for the subsector contested by the candidate, in accordance with this section.
The Commission is to determine the maximum number of counting agents a candidate may appoint.
Only a holder of an identity card who has attained the age of 18 years may be appointed as a counting agent.
A candidate must give notice of appointment of counting agent to the Returning Officer.

subsection.leadIn: A notice of appointment must be given to the Returning Officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at least 7 days before polling day; or (L.N. 114 of 2006; 15 of 2016 s. 41)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on polling day.

subsection.name: 5A
subsection.content: A notice of appointment given under subsection (5)(a) must be delivered by hand, by post, by electronic mail or by facsimile transmission. (15 of 2016 s. 41)

subsection.leadIn: If notice of appointment is given on polling day, it must be delivered to the Returning Officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by the candidate in person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by the election agent of the candidate, in person.

subsection.content: The appointment of a counting agent is not effective until notice of the appointment is received by the Returning Officer.
A notice of appointment must be in writing and in the specified form. It must state the name, identity card number and address of the counting agent. It must be signed by the candidate.
If the appointment of a counting agent is revoked, the candidate must give notice of the revocation to the Returning Officer in accordance with subsection (10A) or (11). (15 of 2016 s. 41)
A notice of revocation must be in writing and in the specified form. It must be signed by the candidate.

subsection.name: 10A
subsection.content: If the notice of revocation is given before polling day, it must be delivered to the Returning Officer by hand, by post, by electronic mail or by facsimile transmission. (15 of 2016 s. 41)
If notice of revocation is given on polling day, it must be delivered to the Returning Officer by the candidate, or the election agent of the candidate, in person. (15 of 2016 s. 41)
The revocation of the appointment of a counting agent is not effective until notice of the revocation is received by the Returning Officer.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Chief Electoral Officer to appoint or remove counting officers

subsection.content: The Chief Electoral Officer may appoint, as counting officers, persons that Officer considers suitable to assist a Returning Officer in the counting of votes.
The Chief Electoral Officer must supply to each Returning Officer a list of the counting officers appointed to assist the Returning Officer.
The Chief Electoral Officer must display the list of counting officers in a prominent place within the relevant counting station or stations.
The Chief Electoral Officer may, at any time, with reasonable cause revoke the appointment of a counting officer. (L.N. 114 of 2006; L.N. 176 of 2006)

section.name: s66
section.heading: Who may be present at counting of votes

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (2) and (6), only the Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors), Returning Officer, Assistant Returning Officer and the following persons may be present at the counting of votes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: counting officers;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: candidates;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: election agents and counting agents;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: members of the Commission;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the Chief Electoral Officer;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: police officers on duty at the counting station;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: members of the Civil Aid Service on duty at the counting station;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: public officers authorized in writing by the Chief Electoral Officer; and

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: persons authorized in writing by a member of the Commission.

subsection.leadIn: No other person may be present at the counting of votes except with the permission of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the counting takes place at a counting zone of a central counting station, the Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors), or the Returning Officer in charge of the counting zone; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the counting takes place at a counting zone of a counting station that is not a central counting station, the Returning Officer who supervises the counting station.

subsection.content: The Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors), and the Returning Officer in charge of the counting zone, are to ensure that the arrangements for the counting of votes at a counting zone of a central counting station are such that the candidates and their respective election agents or counting agents are able to observe how individual votes are counted.

The Returning Officer who supervises a counting station is to ensure that the arrangements for the counting of votes at a counting zone of the counting station are such that the candidates and their respective election agents or counting agents are able to observe how individual votes are counted.

Only an election agent or counting agent regarding whom notice of appointment has been given under this Regulation may be present during the counting of votes at the counting zone. On arriving at the counting station, an election agent or counting agent must report in person to the Returning Officer and produce his or her identity card and a declaration of secrecy completed on the specified form by him or her. (L.N. 75 of 2011)

The Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors) (in the case of a central counting station), or the Returning Officer who supervises the counting station (in the case of a counting station that is not a central counting station), may, if that Officer considers it appropriate and practicable without disrupting the counting of votes and prejudicing the secrecy of the individual votes, permit members of the public to observe the counting of votes from an area at the counting station set apart for that purpose by that Officer. The area is to be at such a distance from the place where the votes are being counted as that Officer considers appropriate.

section.name: s67
section.heading: What constitutes offence at counting station

subsection.leadIn: A person who, during the relevant period, films or takes photographs or makes any audio or video recording within a counting zone of a counting station without the express permission of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case of a central counting station, the Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors), or the Returning Officer in charge of the counting zone; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of a counting station that is not a central counting station, the Returning Officer who supervises the counting station; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any member of the Commission,

subsection.continued: commits an offence.

subsection.def: In subsection (1), relevant period (有關期間) means, in relation to a counting zone, the period commencing from the time, determined under section 63, at which the counting of votes is to begin at the zone and ending upon the completion of the counting and re-count, if any, at the zone.

subsection.leadIn: A person who, at or in the vicinity of a counting station, behaves in a disorderly manner, or fails to comply with a lawful order given by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a central counting station, the Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors), or the Returning Officer in charge of a counting zone of the central counting station; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a counting station that is not a central counting station, the Returning Officer who supervises the counting station,

subsection.continued: commits an offence.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under this section is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

section.name: s68
section.heading: Returning Officers to keep order at counting station

subsection.content: The Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors), and the Returning Officers in charge of a counting zone of a central counting station, must keep order at the central counting station.
The Returning Officer who supervises a counting station must keep order at the counting station.

subsection.leadIn: If a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: misconducts himself or herself at or in the vicinity of—

subparagraph.content: a central counting station, the Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors) may; or
a counting station that is not a central counting station, the Returning Officer who supervises the counting station may;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: at or in the vicinity of a counting station, fails to obey a lawful order of the Returning Officer—

subparagraph.content: who supervises the counting station; or
in charge of a counting zone of the counting station,

subsection.continued: order the person to leave the counting station or the vicinity of the counting station, as the case may be, immediately.

subsection.content: The Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors) or the Returning Officer who supervises a counting station may order a person to leave the counting station immediately if that Officer reasonably considers that, having regard to the conduct of the person, the person’s presence at the counting station is for a purpose other than that for which such presence is permitted or authorized.

If a person fails to leave when ordered to do so under subsection (3) or (4), the person may be removed by a police officer or by a person authorized in writing by the Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors) or the Returning Officer, as may be appropriate.
A person who is removed under subsection (5) may not enter the relevant counting station again on that day unless the Officer who ordered his or her removal permits him or her to do so.

For the purpose of subsection (3) but without limiting it, a person misconducts himself or herself if the person disrupts the counting of votes at the counting station, or disturbs or causes inconvenience to any person in the counting station.

section.name: s69
section.heading: Ballot boxes to be delivered to counting station
section.content: A Presiding Officer must deliver or arrange to be delivered to the counting station designated for the counting of the votes cast at the subsector election concerned, the ballot boxes from that Officer’s polling station, the sealed packets under section 61 and the ballot paper account prepared by that Officer.

section.name: s70
section.heading: Supervision of counting station and separate counting zones

subsection.content: The Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors) is to supervise the central counting station. In a central counting station, the respective Returning Officers for the subsectors are to be in charge of the counting zone for the relevant subsector.
A counting station that is not a central counting station and is designated for the counting of the votes for a subsector election, is to be supervised by the Returning Officer for the subsector.
The Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors) and the Returning Officer are to be assisted by one or more Assistant Returning Officers.

section.name: s71
section.heading: Delivered ballot boxes and ballot paper accounts to be given into charge of relevant Returning Officer

subsection.leadIn: After delivery to a central counting station—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the ballot boxes and ballot paper accounts from a polling station are to be given into the charge of the Returning Officer specified for the purpose by the Chief Electoral Officer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the sealed packets under section 61 are to be given into the charge of the Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors).

subsection.content: If the Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors) considers that the arrangements described in subsection (1) are not practicable, that Officer may modify them.

The ballot boxes, the ballot paper accounts and the sealed packets under section 61 delivered to a counting station that is not a central counting station are to be given into the charge of the Returning Officer who supervises the counting station.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Returning Officer to open ballot box

subsection.content: A Returning Officer into whose charge a ballot box is given must, at the counting zone of which that Officer is in charge, open it by breaking the seal. That Officer must do so in the presence of the candidates, their election agents or counting agents, if present at the counting zone.

The Returning Officer must permit a candidate, or the election agent or counting agent of a candidate, to inspect any paper taken from the ballot box, if so requested by the candidate or agent before the paper is disposed of. A candidate or an election agent or a counting agent must not be permitted under this subsection to inspect a ballot paper.

section.name: s73
section.heading: Arrangements for counting of votes and verification of number of ballot papers in manual counting

subsection.content: This section applies where the votes cast for the candidates at the subsector election concerned are to be counted without the use of a computer.

subsection.leadIn: At a central counting station, the Returning Officer must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to the ballot papers in the ballot boxes that have been given into that Officer’s charge under section 71, at the counting zone of which that Officer is in charge—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: arrange for the ballot papers to be sorted according to each subsector;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: arrange for the number of ballot papers to be counted and recorded for each subsector;
verify the total number of ballot papers recorded for all subsectors under subparagraph (ii) by comparing it with the ballot paper account for that polling station; (8 of 2025 s. 32)

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: prepare a statement in writing as to the result of the verification;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: retain the ballot papers for the subsector for which that Officer is appointed together with the verification of number of ballot papers and the relevant records prepared under subparagraph (ii); (14 of 2021 s. 212; 8 of 2025 s. 32)

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: make into separate bundles the other sorted ballot papers together with the relevant records prepared under subparagraph (ii), place each bundle in a separate receptacle and seal it in the presence of those present at the counting zone; and (14 of 2021 s. 212; 8 of 2025 s. 32)

subparagraph.name: vii
subparagraph.content: arrange for the Assistant Returning Officer in attendance at the counting zone to hand over the receptacles to the Returning Officer for the relevant subsector at the counting zone for that subsector; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to the ballot papers retained by that Officer under paragraph (a)(v) and those handed over to that Officer under paragraph (a)(vii), arrange for the votes recorded on the ballot papers to be counted, without the use of a computer, at the counting zone of which that Officer is in charge.

subsection.leadIn: At a counting station that is not a central counting station, the Returning Officer must, in relation to the ballot papers in the ballot boxes that have been given into that Officer’s charge under section 71—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: arrange for the number of ballot papers to be counted and recorded;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: verify the number recorded under paragraph (a) by comparing it with the ballot paper account; (14 of 2021 s. 212)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: prepare a statement in writing as to the result of the verification; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: arrange for the votes recorded on the ballot papers to be counted without the use of a computer.

subsection.leadIn: In preparing the verification of number of ballot papers, if the Returning Officer considers it necessary or if required by a candidate present at the counting zone or an election agent or a counting agent so present, that Officer must compare the ballot paper accounts with— (14 of 2021 s. 212; 8 of 2025 s. 32)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the total number of ballot papers recorded for all subsectors under subsection (2)(a)(ii) or (3)(a), as the case may be; and (8 of 2025 s. 32)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the number of the counterfoils or un-issued ballot papers, the unused ballot papers and the spoilt ballot papers.

subsection.content: A candidate, an election agent or a counting agent may copy what is recorded on the ballot paper account or the verification of number of ballot papers. (14 of 2021 s. 212)

section.name: s74
section.heading: Arrangements for counting of votes and verification of number of ballot papers in computer counting

subsection.content: This section applies where the votes cast for the candidates at the subsector election concerned are to be counted with the use of a computer.

subsection.leadIn: At a central counting station, the Returning Officer must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to the ballot papers in the ballot boxes that have been given into that Officer’s charge under section 71, arrange for the votes recorded on the ballot papers to be counted with the use of a computer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to the ballot papers the votes recorded on which cannot be counted with the use of a computer, at the counting zone of which that Officer is in charge—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: arrange for the ballot papers to be sorted according to each subsector;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: retain the ballot papers for the subsector for which that Officer is appointed;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: arrange for the number of the other sorted ballot papers to be counted and recorded for each of the other subsectors;

subparagraph.name: iv
v
subparagraph.content: make into separate bundles the other sorted ballot papers together with the relevant statement prepared under subparagraph (iv), place each bundle in a separate receptacle and seal it in the presence of those present at the counting zone; and

subparagraph.name: vi

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in relation to the ballot paper account that has been given into that Officer’s charge under section 71, retain the ballot paper account; and (8 of 2025 s. 33)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in relation to the ballot papers retained by that Officer under paragraph (b)(ii) and those handed over to that Officer under paragraph (b)(vi), arrange for the votes recorded on the ballot papers to be counted, without the use of a computer, at the counting zone of which that Officer is in charge.

subsection.leadIn: At a counting station that is not a central counting station, the Returning Officer must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to the ballot papers in the ballot boxes that have been given into that Officer’s charge under section 71, arrange for the votes recorded on the ballot papers to be counted with the use of a computer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to the ballot papers the votes recorded on which cannot be counted with the use of a computer, arrange for the votes recorded on the ballot papers to be counted without the use of a computer.

subsection.leadIn: After the votes for a subsector election have been counted under subsection (2) or (3), the Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors) (in the case of a central counting station), or the Returning Officer who supervises the counting station (in the case of a counting station that is not a central counting station), must— (8 of 2025 s. 33)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: ascertain the total number of ballot papers in the ballot boxes from— (8 of 2025 s. 33)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the result of the counting of votes; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the number of ballot papers that a Returning Officer decides under section 78 to be ballot papers the votes recorded on which are not to be counted; (8 of 2025 s. 33)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: verify the number ascertained under paragraph (a) by comparing it with all ballot paper accounts received by the central counting station or the counting station that is not a central counting station, as the case may be; and (8 of 2025 s. 33)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: prepare a statement in writing as to the result of the verification.

subsection.leadIn: In preparing the verification of number of ballot papers, if the Officer concerned considers it necessary or if required by a candidate present at the counting zone or an election agent or a counting agent so present, that Officer must compare the ballot paper accounts with— (14 of 2021 s. 213; 8 of 2025 s. 33)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the total number of ballot papers ascertained under subsection (4)(a); and (8 of 2025 s. 33)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the number of the counterfoils or un-issued ballot papers, the unused ballot papers and the spoilt ballot papers.

subsection.content: A candidate, an election agent or a counting agent may copy what is recorded on the ballot paper account or the verification of number of ballot papers. (14 of 2021 s. 213)

section.name: s74A
section.heading: Invalid and questionable ballot papers
section.leadIn: In the course of counting in accordance with section 73(2) or (3), or 74(2) or (3)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: any ballot paper which—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: appears to have any writing or mark by which the voter can possibly be identified;

subparagraph.name: ii
iii
subparagraph.content: appears to be substantially mutilated; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: appears to be void for uncertainty,

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any ballot paper described in section 77(1)(b), (c), (d), (f) and (ga) must be separated and the vote is not to be counted under section 77.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Votes to be counted in accordance with counting system in Schedule to Chief Executive Election Ordinance
section.content: The votes recorded on the ballot papers are to be counted in accordance with the counting system described in section 29 of the Schedule to the Chief Executive Election Ordinance (Cap. 569), whether with or without the use of a computer.

section.name: s76
section.heading: Result of counting of votes and re-count

subsection.content: After the votes for a subsector election have been counted under section 73 or 74, the Returning Officer must make known to the candidates who are present at the counting zone, the result of the counting of votes. If the candidates are not present the Returning Officer is to make known the result to the respective election agents or counting agents of the candidates, if those agents are present at the counting zone.

A candidate who is present when the votes are counted or re-counted or an election agent so present may request the Returning Officer to count again the counted votes or re-counted votes, as the case may be. That Officer must comply with the request unless the Officer is of the opinion that the request is unreasonable.

After a counting of votes or re-count is completed, nothing further is to be done until each candidate present at the completion, or the election agent of each candidate (but not both) if present at the completion of the counting or re-count, is given a reasonable opportunity to make a request for a re-count.

section.name: s77
section.heading: Votes recorded on invalid ballot papers not to be counted

subsection.leadIn: When counting votes, a ballot paper of any of the following descriptions is not to be regarded as valid and the vote recorded on the ballot paper is not to be counted— (L.N. 114 of 2006; L.N. 176 of 2006; L.N. 75 of 2011)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on which there is writing or a mark by which the voter can possibly be identified; (L.N. 114 of 2006)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: which has the words “重複” and “TENDERED” endorsed on the front of it;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: which has the words “未用” and “UNUSED” endorsed on the front of it; (L.N. 75 of 2011)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: which has the words “損壞” and “SPOILT” endorsed on the front of it;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: which is substantially mutilated;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: which is unmarked;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (2), which is not marked in accordance with section 56(1) or (2); (1 of 2019 s. 55)

paragraph.name: ga
paragraph.leadIn: on which votes are recorded for a number of candidates exceeding—

subparagraph.content: for a subsector ordinary election—the number of EC members to be elected by the subsector concerned; or (14 of 2021 s. 214)
for a subsector by-election—the number of EC members to be returned at the by-election; (1 of 2019 s. 55)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: which the Returning Officer determines as being void for uncertainty.

subsection.content: In the case of a ballot paper referred to in subsection (1)(g) that is used for a subsector by-election in relation to which the Commission has made a direction under section 56(2), if the Returning Officer is satisfied that the intention of the voter or authorized representative is clear notwithstanding the deviation from the requirements in section 56(2)(b), that Officer may count the vote recorded on that ballot paper.

For the avoidance of doubt, it is declared that the Returning Officer is not to make a decision not to count the vote recorded on a ballot paper solely because the name of, and other information relating to, a candidate on the ballot paper are crossed out, or endorsed with a marking as directed by the Commission, under section 37(2). (1 of 2019 s. 42; 8 of 2025 s. 34)

subsection.leadIn: A candidate, an election agent or a counting agent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may inspect a ballot paper referred to in subsection (1)(b), (c), (d), (f) or (ga); but (1 of 2019 s. 55)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is not entitled to make representations to the Returning Officer concerning the ballot paper. (L.N. 114 of 2006)

section.name: s78
section.heading: Returning Officer to make decisions on questionable ballot papers

subsection.leadIn: If a ballot paper is forwarded to the Returning Officer under section 74A(a), a candidate, an election agent or a counting agent, if present at the counting of votes, may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: inspect the ballot paper; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: make representations to the Returning Officer concerning the ballot paper. (L.N. 114 of 2006)

subsection.content: After considering the representations, the Returning Officer must make a decision as to whether the vote recorded on the ballot paper is not to be counted under section 77 or is to be counted.

If the Returning Officer decides the vote recorded on a ballot paper is not to be counted, that Officer must endorse the words “不獲接納” and “rejected” on the front of the ballot paper. If a candidate, an election agent or a counting agent objects to the Returning Officer’s decision, that Officer must also add the words “反對此選票不獲接納” and “rejection objected to”. (L.N. 114 of 2006)

If a candidate, an election agent or a counting agent objects to the decision of the Returning Officer to count the vote recorded on a ballot paper, that Officer must endorse the words “反對此選票獲接納” and “acceptance objected to” on that ballot paper. (L.N. 114 of 2006)

section.name: s78A
section.heading: Returning Officer to prepare ballot paper statement

subsection.content: The Returning Officer is to prepare a statement of the ballot papers that are not counted.

subsection.leadIn: The statement is to be made under the following heads—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the ballot paper has on it any writing or mark by which the voter can possibly be identified;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the ballot paper is endorsed with the words “TENDERED” and “重複”;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: the ballot paper is endorsed with the words “SPOILT” and “損壞”;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the ballot paper is substantially mutilated;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the ballot paper is unmarked;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the ballot paper is not marked in accordance with section 56(1) or (2);

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.leadIn: the ballot paper is one on which votes are recorded for a number of candidates exceeding—

subparagraph.content: for a subsector ordinary election—the number of EC members to be elected by the subsector concerned; or (14 of 2021 s. 215)
for a subsector by-election—the number of EC members to be returned at the by-election;

paragraph.content: the ballot paper is void for uncertainty.

section.name: s79
section.heading: Returning Officer’s decision on ballot paper to be final
section.content: Subject to section 39 of the Schedule to the Chief Executive Election Ordinance (Cap. 569), the decision of the Returning Officer on a ballot paper is final.

section.name: s80
section.heading: Returning Officer to declare subsector election result

subsection.content: When the counting of votes and re-counts, if any, are completed and the result of the subsector election determined, the Returning Officer is to declare as elected the candidates who were successful at the subsector election, as provided in section 29(7) of the Schedule to the Chief Executive Election Ordinance (Cap. 569).

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) applies if, before the Returning Officer declares a candidate to be elected—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: proof is given to the satisfaction of the Officer that the candidate has died; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proof is given to the satisfaction of the Candidate Eligibility Review Committee that the candidate is disqualified from being elected. (14 of 2021 s. 216)

subsection.leadIn: In the circumstances mentioned in subsection (1A)(a) or (b), the Returning Officer— (14 of 2021 s. 216)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must not declare that candidate to be elected; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: must—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: declare the candidate to be returned for the subsector under section 29(9) of the Schedule to the Chief Executive Election Ordinance (Cap. 569) to be elected; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if there is no candidate who can be returned under that section, declare that no candidate is returned at the subsector election, as provided in section 26(2)(c) of that Schedule, or that the number of EC members returned at the subsector election for the subsector is less than the number of EC members to be returned at the subsector election, as provided in section 26(2)(d) of that Schedule.

subsection.content: A declaration under section 26(2)(c) or (d) of the Schedule to the Chief Executive Election Ordinance (Cap. 569) is to be made by the Returning Officer by a notice. The notice must be displayed in a prominent place outside the counting station. As soon as practicable after the declaration is made, the notice must be published in the Gazette.

section.name: s81
section.heading: Form in which Returning Officer is to publish result of subsector election

subsection.content: The notice to be published under section 35(1) of the Schedule to the Chief Executive Election Ordinance (Cap. 569) for a subsector election is to be in Form 3 in Schedule 2.
A notice under subsection (1) must be published in the Gazette within 7 days after the date on which the relevant result is declared under section 80. (L.N. 75 of 2011; 14 of 2021 s. 217)
The Returning Officer is to prepare a notice of the result of the subsector election in the appropriate form under this section and display it prominently in a place outside the counting station.

subsection.leadIn: The Returning Officer is to send a copy of each notice prepared under subsection (3) to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chairman;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs; and (L.N. 130 of 2007)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Chief Electoral Officer.

editorialNote.content: For the saving and transitional provisions relating to the amendments made by the Resolution of the Legislative Council (L.N. 130 of 2007), see paragraph (12) of that Resolution.

section.name: s82
section.heading: Returning Officer to seal ballot papers in packets

subsection.leadIn: At a central counting station, the Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors) must, as soon as practicable after the results of the polls for all the subsectors concerned have been ascertained, make up into separate sealed packets in relation to those subsectors—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the ballot papers the votes recorded on which are counted;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the un-issued ballot papers;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the unused ballot papers;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the spoilt ballot papers; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the rejected ballot papers.

subsection.leadIn: At a counting station that is not a central counting station, the Returning Officer must, as soon as practicable after having ascertained the result of the poll for the subsector for which that Officer is appointed, make up into separate sealed packets in relation to that subsector—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the ballot papers the votes recorded on which are counted;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the un-issued ballot papers;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the unused ballot papers;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the spoilt ballot papers; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the rejected ballot papers.

subsection.content: The Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors) or the Returning Officer must endorse on each sealed packet a description of its contents, the date of the relevant subsector election and the name of the subsector.
A candidate or an election agent or a counting agent may be present when the Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors) or the Returning Officer makes up the sealed packets and endorses them.

subsection.leadIn: Before the Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors) or the Returning Officer makes up the packets, that Officer must inform—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the candidates who are present at the counting station; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: either the election agent or counting agent (if present) of a candidate who is not present at the counting station,

subsection.continued: that they may be present when that Officer makes up the packets and seals and endorses them.

section.name: s83
section.heading: Returning Officer to send ballot papers, accounts, packets, etc. to Chief Electoral Officer

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after preparing the notice of the result of the subsector election, the Returning Officer must send to the Chief Electoral Officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the ballot paper accounts and verification of number of ballot papers; (14 of 2021 s. 218)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the statement referred to in section 78A(1); (1 of 2019 s. 58)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (2), the sealed packets made up under section 82;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a copy of the notice of the result of the subsector election;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: all nomination forms;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: notices of withdrawal of candidature, if any;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: notices of appointment of election agents, polling agents and counting agents and copies of authorizations of election expense agents; (14 of 2021 s. 218)

paragraph.name: ga
paragraph.content: if the copy of the subsector final register has been marked under section 53(5)(a)—the marked copy; and (14 of 2021 s. 218)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: any other document relating to the subsector election specified by the Commission.

subsection.content: At a central counting station where the votes are counted with the use of a computer, the sealed packets made up under section 82 are to be sent by the Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors) to the Chief Electoral Officer as soon as practicable after they have been made up.

section.name: s84
section.heading: Ballot paper in custody of Chief Electoral Officer may be inspected only on court order
section.content: The Chief Electoral Officer is not to permit any person to inspect any ballot paper in that Officer’s custody other than on an order made by a Revising Officer in an appeal under section 39 of the Schedule to the Chief Executive Election Ordinance (Cap. 569) or on an order of court made in criminal proceedings.

section.name: s85
section.heading: Chief Electoral Officer to retain subsector election documents for at least 6 months
section.content: The Chief Electoral Officer must retain in that Officer’s custody the documents sent to that Officer under section 83 and the copies or extracts of the subsector final register in which records have been made under section 53(5)(b) for at least 6 months from the date of the subsector election to which they relate. That Officer must thereafter, unless directed by an order of the Revising Officer in an appeal under section 39 of the Schedule to the Chief Executive Election Ordinance (Cap. 569) or by an order of court made in criminal proceedings, destroy them.

part.name: P6
part.heading: Miscellaneous and Supplemental Provisions: Subsector Elections

section.name: s86
section.heading: Returning Officers, Presiding Officers, polling officers or counting officers not to act as agent of candidate in same subsector election

subsection.content: A Returning Officer, Presiding Officer, polling officer or counting officer who, in relation to the subsector election for which he or she is appointed, acts as an election agent, a polling agent, a counting agent or an election expense agent, commits an offence.
A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

section.name: s87
section.heading: Employees of candidates not to act as electoral officers

subsection.content: A person who, while in the employment of a candidate, acts as a Returning Officer, Presiding Officer, polling officer or counting officer at a subsector election for which the candidate stands for election, commits an offence.
A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

section.name: s87A
section.heading: Certain visitors of voters or authorized representatives in custody not to canvass for votes

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person (visitor) visits in a certain capacity a voter in custody or an authorized representative in custody for a business or official purpose; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: another person who is not acting in that capacity is not allowed to visit the voter or authorized representative for that purpose,

subsection.continued: the visitor commits an offence if he or she, during the visit, canvasses for votes for the purpose of an election.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

section.name: s88
section.heading: Presiding Officer may perform functions through polling officers

subsection.content: A Presiding Officer may perform any act which that Officer is required or authorized to perform under this Regulation through a polling officer.
The power to adjourn a poll under section 2(1) of Schedule 1 must be exercised by the Presiding Officer personally.

section.name: s89
section.heading: Returning Officer may perform functions through Assistant Returning Officers

subsection.content: A Returning Officer may perform any act which that Officer is required or authorized to perform under this Regulation through an Assistant Returning Officer appointed for the subsector for which the Returning Officer is appointed.

subsection.leadIn: A Returning Officer may not delegate under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a decision regarding a ballot paper; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the declaration of the result of the subsector election.

section.name: s90
section.heading: Chief Electoral Officer to be subject to direction of Commission

subsection.content: The Chief Electoral Officer is subject to the directions of the Commission in the performance of that Officer’s functions under this Regulation.
The Chief Electoral Officer may delegate that Officer’s powers, duties or functions under this Regulation to a member of the staff provided under section 9(3) of the Ordinance.

section.name: s91
section.heading: Acts done in absence of candidates or agents not to be invalid
section.content: Where under this Regulation, an act or thing is required or authorized to be done in the presence of a candidate or all the candidates, the election agent, the polling agent or the counting agent of the candidate, that act or thing is not to be invalidated solely for the reason that such person or persons were not present as required or authorized.

section.name: s92
section.heading: Electoral officers, candidates and agents to make declaration of secrecy

subsection.content: Every electoral officer (within the meaning of paragraph (d), (e), (g) or (h) of the definition of electoral officer in section 2(1) of the Chief Executive Election Ordinance (Cap. 569)), every person (other than such an electoral officer) who is appointed under that Ordinance or the Ordinance to perform functions at or in connection with a subsector election, or every person authorized by or under this Regulation to attend at a polling station except as a voter or an authorized representative must, before entering the polling station, make a declaration of secrecy on the specified form.

Every candidate, election agent, counting agent or counting officer or other person (except as a member of the public under section 66(6)) authorized by or under this Regulation to attend at the counting of votes must, before entering the counting station, make a declaration of secrecy on the specified form. (L.N. 114 of 2006)

The Returning Officer is to make the declaration in the presence of a Commissioner for Oaths. Any other person may make the declaration in the presence of the Returning Officer, a Commissioner for Oaths, a member of the Commission, the Chief Electoral Officer or a person whose official designation is that of a deputy to the Chief Electoral Officer.
Every Returning Officer or other officer or any other person attending at a polling station or the counting of votes must maintain and assist in maintaining the secrecy of the ballot.

Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply to a police officer, an officer of the Correctional Services Department, an officer of any law enforcement agency or a member of the Civil Aid Service on duty at a polling station or a counting station. (L.N. 132 of 2009)

section.name: s93
section.heading: Enforcement of provisions as to secrecy

subsection.content: A person who divulges to any other person, by communicating information as to the name or identity document number in a register of voters, or otherwise, whether a person has or has not applied for a ballot paper or voted, commits an offence.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: A person who divulges to any other person the identity of a voter in custody commits an offence. (L.N. 132 of 2009)

Subsections (1) and (1A) do not apply to anything done for a purpose authorized by law or when required to do so by a police officer or an officer of the Independent Commission Against Corruption investigating an offence under the Ordinance, any regulation made under the Ordinance, the Elections (Corrupt and Illegal Conduct) Ordinance (Cap. 554), sections 3, 4 and 8 of the Prevention of Bribery Ordinance (Cap. 201) or section 13B of the Independent Commission Against Corruption Ordinance (Cap. 204). (L.N. 132 of 2009)
A person who communicates to any other person any information obtained at a counting of votes as to the candidate for whom a vote has been given on any particular ballot paper, commits an offence.
A person who interferes with a voter when the voter is recording the vote, commits an offence.

A person who interferes with or attempts to interfere with any ballot boxes, un-issued ballot papers, tendered ballot papers, unused ballot papers, spoilt ballot papers, marked ballot papers or a copy of the subsector final register in printed form marked under section 53(5)(a), commits an offence. (14 of 2021 s. 221)

A person who interferes with or attempts to interfere with any opened ballot boxes, ballot paper accounts, verifications of number of ballot papers or any other relevant subsector election materials referred to in this Regulation, commits an offence. (14 of 2021 s. 221)

subsection.leadIn: A person who obtains or attempts to obtain in any manner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: within a polling station or a no staying zone; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: within a no canvassing zone, without the express permission of the Presiding Officer or the Commission,

subsection.continued: information as to the candidate for whom a voter in the polling station is about to vote or has voted, commits an offence.

subsection.content: A person who communicates at any time to any person any information obtained in a polling station as to the candidate for whom a voter is about to vote or has voted, commits an offence.

A person who directly or indirectly induces a voter to display the voter’s ballot paper after the voter has marked it so as to make known to any person a candidate for or against whom the voter has voted, commits an offence.
A person who commits an offence under this section is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (L.N. 114 of 2006)

subsection.def: In this section, voter (投票人) includes an authorized representative.

section.name: s94
section.heading: Procedure in case of death or disqualification of candidate on polling day but before declaration of result

subsection.leadIn: If, on or after the date of a subsector election but before the declaration of the result of the subsector election—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: proof is given to the satisfaction of the Returning Officer that a candidate for the subsector election has died; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proof is given to the satisfaction of the Candidate Eligibility Review Committee that a candidate for the subsector election is disqualified from being elected,

subsection.continued: the Returning Officer must direct that the proceedings for the subsector election are to begin or to continue, as the case may be, as if the death or disqualification had not occurred. (14 of 2021 s. 222)

subsection.content: If, after the votes are counted, the deceased or disqualified candidate is found to be successful at the subsector election, section 80(2) applies.
If the deceased or disqualified candidate is not successful at the subsector election, the Returning Officer must declare the successful candidate to be elected as provided in section 80(1).

section.name: s95
section.heading: Publication and display of notices, etc.

subsection.content: The Returning Officer or the Presiding Officer may publish or display a notice, determination, or other writing under this Regulation in a manner that Officer thinks fit except where specific provision is made for the publication or display in this Regulation. (L.N. 114 of 2006)

subsection.leadIn: The following notices or notifications may be delivered by hand, by post, by electronic mail or by facsimile transmission— (15 of 2016 s. 42)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notice of the decision of the Candidate Eligibility Review Committee as to whether a person is validly nominated as a candidate; (14 of 2021 s. 223)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: notice of a declaration that a candidate has died or that the decision of the Candidate Eligibility Review Committee has been varied to the effect that a candidate is not validly nominated; (14 of 2021 s. 223)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: notice to Returning Officers and to candidates of the determination of a no canvassing zone and a no staying zone;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: notice to Returning Officers and to candidates of the variation before polling day of a no canvassing zone or a no staying zone;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: notice to candidates of the arrangements for the drawing of lots to determine the order of appearance of candidates on the ballot papers; and

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: notice to candidates of the time and place for the counting of votes.

subsection.content: Notice of variation of a no canvassing zone or a no staying zone on the polling day or notice of the resumption of the counting of votes after an adjourned poll or counting may be given orally if notice by hand, by post, by electronic mail or by facsimile transmission is not practicable or is not suitable in the circumstances.

section.name: s96
section.heading: Commission to designate Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors)
section.content: The Commission may designate a Returning Officer as the Chief Returning Officer (Subsectors).

section.name: s96A
section.heading: Election return to be lodged in specified form
section.content: The election return required to be lodged under section 37 of the Elections (Corrupt and Illegal Conduct) Ordinance (Cap. 554) in respect of an ordinary election or a by-election must be in the specified form (if any).

section.name: s97
section.heading: Commission to specify forms

subsection.content: The Commission may specify forms for the purpose of this Regulation.
The Chief Electoral Officer is to make available during ordinary business hours at that Officer’s office and at the office of each Returning Officer, the forms specified under subsection (1).
The Chief Electoral Officer may make the forms specified under subsection (1) available at any other place that Officer considers appropriate.
Forms specified under subsection (1) are to be made available free of charge.

Subsections (2), (3) and (4) do not apply to the specified forms for the subsector election notices, notice published under section 18 or 19, notification by the Chief Electoral Officer of the particulars of election agents, notice of guidance to voters referred to in section 39, ballot papers, ballot paper account or notice of the subsector election result.
The Commission may specify forms for notifications by the Returning Officer under the Election Committee (Subscribers and Election Deposit for Nomination) Regulation (Cap. 569 sub. leg. C).

section.name: s98
section.heading: Reporting of irregularities

subsection.content: If the Chief Electoral Officer, Returning Officer or Presiding Officer is of the opinion that an irregularity has occurred in relation to a subsector election, a poll or a counting of votes, the relevant Officer must make a report in writing to the Commission.

A report of an irregularity must be made as soon as practicable after the relevant Officer becomes aware of it, but it must in any case be made within 14 days after the polling day of the subsector election to which it relates.

If it appears to an Officer referred to in subsection (1) that an occurrence which that Officer considers to be a material irregularity has taken place or is likely to take place in relation to a subsector election, that Officer must make a report to the Commission immediately in a manner that Officer considers expedient in the circumstances.

If a report is made under subsection (3) otherwise than in writing, the Officer concerned must make a report also in writing as soon as practicable, and in any event within 30 days after the polling day of the relevant subsector election.

section.name: s99
section.heading: Letters that may be sent free of postage by candidates

subsection.leadIn: A letter that may be sent free of postage by or on behalf of a candidate under section 38(1) of the Schedule to the Chief Executive Election Ordinance (Cap. 569) must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be posted in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to section 38(2A) of the Schedule to the Chief Executive Election Ordinance (Cap. 569), contain materials relating only to the candidate’s candidature at the subsector election concerned; (18 of 2011 s. 37)

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: be not larger than 165 mm × 245 mm and not smaller than 90 mm × 140 mm in size; and (11 of 2019 s. 22)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: not exceed 5 mm in thickness at any part of the letter. (11 of 2019 s. 22)

subsection.leadIn: If letters are sent, in a bulk mailing, free of postage by or on behalf of a candidate under section 38(1) of the Schedule to the Chief Executive Election Ordinance (Cap. 569), the candidate or any person authorized by the candidate must provide the Postmaster General with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a specimen of the materials contained in that bulk mailing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a declaration, in the specified form, signed by the candidate or the person and stating that the materials contained in that bulk mailing are identical with the specimen provided to the Postmaster General.

subsection.leadIn: If, in relation to any letters sent, in a bulk mailing, free of postage by or on behalf of a candidate under section 38(1) of the Schedule to the Chief Executive Election Ordinance (Cap. 569)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any letter in that bulk mailing does not comply with subsection (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a declaration under subsection (2)(b) is false in any particular,

subsection.continued: the candidate is liable for payment of postage for all the letters in that bulk mailing.

section.name: s101
section.heading: Offence of false declaration

subsection.content: A person who, in an election related document, makes a statement which that person knows to be false in a material particular or recklessly makes a statement which is incorrect in a material particular or knowingly omits a material particular from an election related document, commits an offence.

A person who directly or indirectly by himself or herself or another person on his or her behalf conspires with, incites, compels, induces, coerces, intimidates or persuades another person to make a false statement in an election related document or to provide information which that person knows to be wrong in a material particular in an election related document, commits an offence.
A person who commits an offence under this section is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

An offence under subsection (1) or (2) is to be an offence prescribed for the purposes of section 14 of, and sections 9 and 18 of the Schedule to, the Chief Executive Election Ordinance (Cap. 569). (15 of 2016 s. 69)

subsection.def: In this section, election related document (與選舉有關的文件) means a form, declaration, application, authorization, notice, statement or a nomination form required or used for the purposes of this Regulation.

section.name: s107
section.heading: Interpretation (Part 7)

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: Court (法院) means the Court of First Instance;

def.name: ElectionPeriod
def.leadIn: election period (選舉期), in relation to an election, means the period—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: beginning on the first day of the nomination period; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: ending on—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the day on which a declaration is made under section 19 or 22; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the day on which the polling ends;

subsection.def: open platform (公開平台) means a platform operated through the Internet to which the public has access without having to go through an access control process put in place for that platform;
printed election advertisement (印刷選舉廣告) means an election advertisement printed on any material;
printer (印刷人), in relation to a printed article, includes any person who reproduces the article by any means;
publish (發布) means print, display, exhibit, distribute, post up, publicly announce or make publicly known by any other means, and includes continue to publish.

subsection.content: Any person who authorizes the publication of an election advertisement is taken to have published the advertisement for the purposes of this Part.
If a Returning Officer has not been appointed for a subsector, any reference in this Part to a Returning Officer is to be construed as a reference to the Chief Electoral Officer.

subsection.leadIn: A document published by a candidate during an election period that gives details of the work done by the candidate in the capacity of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chief Executive;

paragraph.name: ab
paragraph.content: an EC member; (14 of 2021 s. 224)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a member of the Legislative Council;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a member of a District Council;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a member of the Heung Yee Kuk;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the Chairman or Vice-Chairman or a member of the Executive Committee of a Rural Committee within the meaning of section 3(3)(a) of the Heung Yee Kuk Ordinance (Cap. 1097); or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a Rural Representative, (5 of 2014 s. 2)

subsection.continued: is an election advertisement for the purposes of this Part.

section.name: s108
section.heading: Requirements applicable to election advertisements

subsection.leadIn: A candidate who publishes an election advertisement must comply with subsection (2) or (3) in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the advertisement and any information related to the advertisement required by the Commission;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the publication is by means of displaying the advertisement in the form of a bill or poster within the meaning of section 104E(4) of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance (Cap. 132), the permission obtained for the purposes of section 104A(1) of that Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the advertisement is of a kind referred to in subsection (1) or (2) of section 27 of the Elections (Corrupt and Illegal Conduct) Ordinance (Cap. 554), the consent referred to in subsection (1A), (1B), (2A) or (2B) of that section.

subsection.leadIn: A candidate must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make an electronic copy of the advertisement, information, permission or consent available for inspection on an open platform maintained by the Chief Electoral Officer or a person authorized by the Chief Electoral Officer (Central Platform) in the manner and within the time specified by the Commission;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: make an electronic copy of the advertisement, information, permission or consent available for inspection on an open platform maintained by the candidate or a person authorized by the candidate (Candidate’s Platform) in the manner and within the time specified by the Commission until the end of the period for which copies of election returns are available for inspection under section 41 of the Elections (Corrupt and Illegal Conduct) Ordinance (Cap. 554) and provide information about the Candidate’s Platform required by the Commission in the manner and within the time specified by the Commission; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the Commission considers that it is technically impracticable to make available for inspection on the Central Platform or a Candidate’s Platform an election advertisement published through the Internet by means of an open platform, provide a hyperlink to that open platform on the Central Platform or Candidate’s Platform in the manner and within the time specified by the Commission.

subsection.leadIn: A candidate must provide, in the manner and within the time specified by the Commission, to the Returning Officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the information and 2 copies of the advertisement in paper form or any other form specified by the Commission; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a hard copy of the permission or consent.

subsection.leadIn: A person must not publish a printed election advertisement that fails to show, in the English or Chinese language—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name and address of the printer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date on which it was printed; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the number of copies printed.

subsection.content: Subsection (4) does not apply to an election advertisement that is printed in a newspaper registered under section 7 of the Registration of Local Newspapers Ordinance (Cap. 268).

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (4) does not apply to the publication of a printed election advertisement if, not later than 7 days after the advertisement is published, the publisher, or a person authorized by the publisher, has provided to the Returning Officer a statutory declaration that states—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name and address of the printer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date on which it was printed; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the number of copies printed.

subsection.content: The Returning Officer must make available for public inspection a copy of each of any advertisement, information, permission, consent or statutory declaration provided under subsection (3) or (6) from when it is provided until the end of the period for which copies of election returns are available for inspection under section 41 of the Elections (Corrupt and Illegal Conduct) Ordinance (Cap. 554).

The Chief Electoral Officer must publicize any platform maintained under subsection (2)(a) and ensure that the platform is maintained until the end of the period for which copies of election returns are available for inspection under section 41 of the Elections (Corrupt and Illegal Conduct) Ordinance (Cap. 554).
A person who fails to comply with subsection (1) or (4) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s109
section.heading: Court may grant relief for election advertisements

subsection.content: A person who publishes an election advertisement without complying with section 108(1)(a) or (4) may apply to the Court for an order under subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: On the hearing of an application made under subsection (1), the Court may make an order excepting the act which would, but for the order, constitute an offence under subsection (9) of section 108, from the relevant requirement under that section, but only if the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: is satisfied that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the non-compliance was due to inadvertence, an accidental miscalculation or any reasonable cause and was not due to bad faith; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the Court requires notice of the application to be given in Hong Kong, the notice has been given; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: believes it to be just that the act be so excepted.

subsection.content: If an application is made under subsection (1), no prosecution against the applicant for not having complied with section 108(1)(a) or (4) may be instituted or carried on until the application is disposed of by the Court.

An applicant is not liable to be convicted of an offence under section 108(9) if the non-compliance by the applicant with section 108(1)(a) or (4) is the subject of an order made under subsection (2).

section.name: s110
section.heading: Power to seize, etc. election advertisements
section.content: The Returning Officer or any person authorized by that Officer may seize and dispose of, or destroy, or obliterate, or cover with any materials that Officer or the person thinks fit, any election advertisement on display and in respect of which any requirement in section 108 has not been complied with.

section.name: s111
section.heading: Commission may grant exemption
section.content: The Commission may, by notice published in the Gazette, exempt any class or type of election advertisement from the application of any provision of section 108.

part.name: P8
part.heading: Electronic Copy or Extract of Subsector Final Register for Purposes of Section 53(5)(b)

section.name: s112
section.heading: Interpretation (Part 8)
section.def: obtain access (取覽), in relation to an FR electronic copy or extract, includes causing an electronic device to perform a function so as to obtain access to the data or information contained in the FR electronic copy or extract.

section.name: s113
section.heading: FR electronic copy or extract

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may, for the purposes of section 53(5)(b), create and maintain an electronic copy or extract of the subsector final register, or of part of the subsector final register—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to be stored on an electronic platform; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: access to which can be obtained through the Internet by using an electronic device.

subsection.content: An FR electronic copy or extract is to contain the identity document numbers of the voters and authorized representatives and such additional particulars or information that the Chief Electoral Officer thinks fit to include.

section.name: s114
section.heading: Protection of FR electronic copy or extract

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if the person obtains access to an FR electronic copy or extract without legal authority to do so.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), an individual has legal authority to obtain access to an FR electronic copy or extract if—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the individual is a Presiding Officer or polling officer who is authorized by the Commission to use the FR electronic copy or extract for the purposes of section 53(5)(b) and the individual so uses the FR electronic copy or extract in compliance with the terms of the authorization; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the individual is authorized by the Commission to assist in making the FR electronic copy or extract available for the use mentioned in paragraph (b) and the individual acts in compliance with the terms of the authorization.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person, without lawful excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: damages any data or information contained in an FR electronic copy or extract; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: otherwise tampers with an FR electronic copy or extract to make its operation defective.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) or (3) is liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 2 years.

section.name: s115
section.heading: Commission may authorize access to FR electronic copy or extract

subsection.leadIn: A member of the Commission may, for the purposes of section 114(2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: grant an authorization to an individual; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: determine the terms of the authorization.

subsection.leadIn: An authorization granted to an individual under subsection (1) must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be in writing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the name and appropriate identification details of the individual; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: set out the terms of the authorization.

schedule.name: sch1
schedule.heading: Postponement and Adjournment of Subsector Elections

section.name: s1
section.heading: Postponement of subsector election and adjournment of poll or counting of votes in respect of subsector election

subsection.content: If, during or before a subsector election, it appears to the Commission that the subsector election is likely to be obstructed, disrupted, undermined or seriously affected by an occurrence specified in subsection (3), the Commission may postpone the subsector election by making a declaration under section 3.

If, at any time during the poll or the counting of votes in respect of a subsector election, it appears to the Commission that the poll at all the polling stations, or the counting of votes at all the counting stations, for the subsector concerned is likely to be obstructed, disrupted, undermined or seriously affected by an occurrence specified in subsection (3), the Commission may adjourn the poll at all the polling stations, or the counting of votes at all the counting stations, for that subsector by making a declaration under section 3.

subsection.leadIn: The occurrences for the purposes of subsections (1) and (2) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a typhoon or other climatic condition of a serious nature;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: riot, open violence or any danger to public health or safety; or (15 of 2016 s. 51)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an occurrence which appears to the Commission to be a material irregularity relating to the subsector election, the poll or the counting of votes.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Adjournment of poll at particular polling station

subsection.content: If, at any time during a poll in respect of a subsector election, it appears to the Presiding Officer that the poll at the polling station is likely to be obstructed, disrupted, undermined or seriously affected by an occurrence specified in subsection (2), the Presiding Officer may adjourn the poll at that polling station by making a declaration under section 3.

subsection.leadIn: The occurrences for the purposes of subsection (1) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a typhoon or other climatic condition of a serious nature;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: riot, open violence or any danger to public health or safety; or (15 of 2016 s. 52)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an occurrence which appears to the Presiding Officer to be a material irregularity relating to the subsector election or the poll.

section.name: s3
section.heading: How declaration for purposes of sections 1 and 2 is to be made and what it is to contain

subsection.content: A declaration for the purposes of sections 1 and 2 is to be made by a notice published in the Gazette. If publication in the Gazette is not practicable in the circumstances, the notice may be published by other means determined by the Commission.

subsection.leadIn: The declaration must contain the following as may be appropriate in each case—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the fact that the subsector election is being postponed;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the fact that the poll or the counting of votes is being adjourned;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a statement as to whether the poll or the counting of votes is being adjourned at all the polling stations or counting stations;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a statement as to whether the poll or the counting of votes is being adjourned at a single polling station or counting station or certain polling stations or counting stations; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a description (by name or otherwise) of the polling stations or counting stations at which the poll or the counting of votes is being adjourned.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Procedure after adjournment of poll
